Passing the buck as Darin W is looking at other source lookup problems.
Step one: I have reproduced the problem as described.

Discovered that the build path for "org.eclipse.swt.tests" specifies a non-
existant source attachment. Rather than referencing "org.junit" as a required 
project, there is a variable on the "libraries" tab of the build path that 
points to the "junit.jar", and specifies an incorrect source attachment. The 
(workaround) is to remove the variable, and add "org.junit" as a required 
project.

We have a bug because our source lookup tried to find the source in a non-
existant jar, and then threw an exception which short-circuited the source 
lookup.

Released fix to HEAD such that the source lookup continues (and works). Need to 
find better way to report error to the user. An error does appear in the log, 
and an error appears on the "source attachement" property of the bogus 
variable. However, the user does not see the error at runtime.

No futher action planned. There is no longer a runtime exception. The result 
will be that the user sees that source is not found when debugging. This is 
enough of an "error indication". The source attachment dialogs do not let you 
enter invalid/non-existent source attachements, so this only happens when a pre-
existing source attachement goes missing.
